title: Don't test for exact equality of floating point numbers
summary:
A discussion came up on Guido von Rossum's Google Plus post. It comes down to the fact that 2.1 is not exactly represented as a floating point number. Internally it's 2.0999999999999996, and this causes unexpected behavior.

These kinds of issues often come up. The confusion is caused by treating floating point numbers as exact numbers, and expecting calculations with them to produce results
